name: Build Expanded Form to 120
notes: Layer unit, ten, and extra cards to model numbers before recording the matching expanded notation.

name: Convert Expanded Form to Standard Form
notes: Recombine expanded card strings and bead bars into standard numerals with self-check prompts.

name: Hundred Chart Neighbor Paths
notes: Trace vertical and horizontal moves on the digital hundred board to highlight near-number relationships.

name: Hundred Chart Pattern Investigation
notes: Color multiples of 5 and 10, then read and compare highlighted entries to describe emerging patterns.

name: Skip Count with Bead Chains
notes: Walk bead chains in sets of twos and fives before recording the sequence on the counting mat.

name: Mixed Skip-Counting Challenges
notes: Follow jump cards on the hundred board to alternate between twos, fives, and tens.

name: Strip Board Two-Digit Addition
notes: Layer tens and ones strips to model two-digit sums that do not require exchanging.

name: Stamp Game Double-Digit Addition
notes: Exchange unit tiles for tens during addition and extend the strategy to three addends.

name: Build Three-Digit Numbers
notes: Compose hundreds, tens, and ones with bead material, then record the numeral that matches the build.

name: Explain Three-Digit Place Value
notes: Describe the value of each digit using stamp tiles and complete explanatory sentence frames.

name: Compare Hundreds with Models
notes: Load bead bars on each side of the scale to decide which three-digit number is greater.

name: Order Three-Digit Numbers
notes: Place number cards on the line, use comparison symbols, and arrange sets from least to greatest.

name: Bundle Tens into Hundreds
notes: Trade ten ten-bars for a hundred square and document the exchange with place-value cards.

name: Decompose Hundreds Strategically
notes: Break apart hundreds into tens and ones to solve multi-step scenarios and explain the role of zeros.

name: Navigate the Thousand Chart
notes: Slide place-value markers along a thousand chart strip to anchor benchmarks and count by hundreds.

name: Thousand Chart Pattern Stories
notes: Describe vertical and diagonal patterns that emerge while moving across thousand chart strips.

name: Benchmark Points on Number Lines
notes: Use bead markers to anchor 0, midpoint, and endpoint values before labeling intermediate numbers.

name: Estimate on Open Number Lines
notes: Place approximate hops on an open number line to predict sums and differences quickly.

name: Locate Multiples of Ten
notes: Hop along bead markers to land on tens and identify numbers that fall between them.

name: Locate Numbers to 1,000
notes: Partition an open number line into equal segments to position three-digit numbers accurately.

name: Skip Count by Tens on Number Lines
notes: Place equal jumps of ten on an open number line and annotate each landing point.

name: Skip Count Mixed Intervals
notes: Alternate jumps of five and ten on a shared number line to notice repeating structures.

name: Stamp Game Make-Ten Bridge
notes: Exchange unit stamps for a ten to model the make-ten addition bridge before recording equations.

name: Decompose to Make Ten
notes: Use jumps on a number line to split addends and show how the make-ten strategy simplifies sums.

name: Two-Digit Addition Strategies
notes: Model addition with bead bars, then shift to written strategies while explaining the regrouping logic.

name: Addition Word Problems within 100
notes: Represent multi-step addition stories with bar models before recording and solving the equation.

name: Two-Digit Subtraction Strategies
notes: Model exchanges on the strip board and narrate the place-value reasoning behind each subtraction step.

name: Subtraction Word Problems within 100
notes: Translate take-away scenarios into bar-model diagrams and solve using recorded regrouping steps.

name: Sort Even and Odd Collections
notes: Pair counters in trays to decide whether sets are even or odd and apply parity rules to numerals.

name: Even/Odd Pattern Investigation
notes: Extend number sequences and describe why sums or differences of even/odd numbers follow predictable patterns.

name: Strategies for Facts within 20
notes: Sort fact cards by strategy (doubles, make-ten, count-on) and justify each efficient choice.

name: Facts within 20 Word Problems
notes: Apply fluent facts to quick story mats that mix addition and subtraction contexts.

name: Build Equal Groups
notes: Group bead bars into matching sets and record the repeated-addition sentence that names the total.

name: Arrays and Early Multiplication
notes: Cover the pattern board with rows and columns of tiles, then write the related multiplication equation.

name: Solve Additive Word Problems
notes: Use comparison bars to plan solutions and articulate which strategy fits the context.

name: Comparison Situations with Addition
notes: Model 'how many more/less' contexts with bar diagrams before writing the matching equation.

name: Compare with Bar Models
notes: Translate comparison statements into diagrams, highlight the unknown, and solve using related facts.

name: Select Measurement Tools
notes: Drag measurement scenarios onto the shelf to match appropriate tools and units.

name: Measure with Rulers
notes: Align digital rulers to objects, emphasize starting at zero, and record measurements in both units.

name: Estimate and Compare Lengths
notes: Predict lengths, measure to confirm, and analyze differences when switching measurement units.

name: Add and Subtract Lengths
notes: Model combined lengths on an open number line and interpret the result in measurement stories.

name: Create Measurement Line Plots
notes: Record repeated measurements in a table and transfer the data to a line plot with unit labels.

name: Build Picture Graphs
notes: Convert tally data into scaled picture graphs and answer comparison questions.

name: Analyse Line Plots
notes: Plot class measurement data and interpret maximum, minimum, and difference questions.

name: Tell Time to Five Minutes
notes: Spin the Montessori clock to show five-minute increments and record the matching time statements.

name: Count Mixed Coins
notes: Drag virtual coins into counting strips and state the running total aloud.

name: Make Target Amounts
notes: Build a required amount with coins, then optimise to use the fewest pieces possible.

name: Time and Money Story Problems
notes: Tackle multi-step problems that mix elapsed time and coin values using bar models.

name: Partition Shapes into Equal Parts
notes: Use draggable partition bars to split circles and rectangles into equal halves and fourths.

name: Describe Fractional Parts
notes: Shade and label fractional regions, then explain how many unit parts form the whole.

name: Tile Rectangles with Arrays
notes: Cover rectangles with unit squares, count rows and columns, and connect to multiplication sentences.

name: Scaled Bar Graph Construction
notes: Build scaled picture and bar graphs with Montessori counters, then answer how many more/less questions using the completed display.

name: Interpret Data Representations
notes: Match story situations to bar, picture, or line graphs and use bar models to compute answers from the selected display.

name: Division as Equal Grouping
notes: Use bead bars to build equal groups, translate the structure to repeated subtraction on a number line, and record the matching division equation.

name: Division as Sharing Equally
notes: Distribute counters into sorting trays to model sharing situations, connect the result to multiplication, and record the matching equation.

name: Relate Division and Multiplication
notes: Cover the pattern board with arrays to show inverse multiplication/division relationships and discuss efficient related-fact strategies.

name: Solve Equal Groups Word Problems
notes: Use bar models to analyze equal-group stories, decide whether to multiply or divide, and justify the solution path.

name: Balance Equations with Unknowns
notes: Use the digital balance to maintain equality while replacing unknowns with numbers, then graph related inequalities on a number line.

name: Arithmetic Pattern Machine
notes: Program a digital function machine with repeated addition or multiplication rules, then describe the pattern using properties.

name: Generate Equivalent Fractions
notes: Partition shapes and number lines to show equivalent fractions and justify the multiplicative relationship between numerator and denominator.

name: Fractions on Number Lines
notes: Mark equal jumps on bead-linked number lines to locate and compare unit and non-unit fractions, including wholes represented as fractions.

name: Compare Fractions
notes: Use fraction insets to reason about the size of unit fractions and justify comparisons with like numerators or denominators.

name: Fractions of Sets and Division
notes: Distribute beads into equal groups to model fractions of sets, compute the fractional amount, and explain the link to division.

name: Fraction Line Plots
notes: Collect fractional measurement data (halves, fourths, eighths) and display it on a line plot before answering comparison questions.

name: Measure Mass with Scales
notes: Use gram weights on a digital balance scale to determine the mass of classroom objects and record the findings.

name: Measure Liquid Volume
notes: Fill graduated Montessori pitchers to given marks to compare and combine liquid volumes.

name: Mass and Volume Story Problems
notes: Use bar models and measurement logs to solve real-world mass and liquid volume problems.

name: Tile Rectangles for Area
notes: Cover rectangles with unit squares, record the area in square units, and connect to multiplication facts.

name: Rectilinear Area Investigation
notes: Decompose rectilinear figures and right triangles into rectangles, calculate area for each part, and justify the total.

name: Perimeter Walk
notes: Trace the border of rectangles and composite shapes, then apply perimeter formulas to compute the total boundary length.

name: Rounding with Bead Ladders
notes: Use bead ladders to compare numbers to the nearest ten and hundred, highlighting which benchmark they approach.

name: Rounding on Number Lines
notes: Place numbers on open number lines, identify the closest benchmark, explain the rounding choice, and apply it to context problems.

name: Estimation Strategy Lab
notes: Compare rounding, front-end estimation, and number-line jumps to choose efficient strategies for estimating sums and differences.

name: Stamp Game Addition within 1,000
notes: Add three-digit numbers with regrouping using the stamp game, then generalize the written algorithm.

name: Stamp Game Subtraction within 1,000
notes: Model exchanges across hundreds, tens, and ones to subtract within 1,000 and apply the strategy to contextual problems.

name: Place Value Problem Lab
notes: Use place-value disks and bar models to interpret multi-step problems involving hundreds, tens, and ones.

name: Plan Multi-Step Solutions
notes: Break complex stories into sequential bars, write supporting equations, and justify the overall plan.

name: Solve Two-Step Word Problems
notes: Execute two-step solution plans with bar models, record each equation, and verify the final answer.

name: Multiplication Fact Strategy Lab
notes: Use bead bars and area models to apply commutative, identity, and doubling strategies to multiplication facts.

name: Distributive and Associative Strategies
notes: Decompose arrays and regroup factors to apply distributive and associative reasoning for larger facts.

name: Multiplication/Division Fact Families
notes: Use triangle boards to generate and apply fact families that connect multiplication and division.

name: Division Fact Strategies
notes: Apply related multiplication facts, repeated subtraction, and area models to evaluate division expressions.

name: Mixed Fact Fluency Studio
notes: Rotate through timed-yet-self-correcting practice, strategy reflection, and context problems mixing multiplication and division facts.

name: Static Multiplication Arrays
notes: Build and record arrays to compute products, explain the model, and find unknown factors or quotients.

name: Elapsed Time on Timelines
notes: Use joint clock and timeline models to find elapsed time, missing starts, or end times to the nearest minute.

name: Hundred Chart Pattern Explorer
notes: Highlight addition and multiplication patterns on the hundred board, then record the rule that generates the table.

name: Multiply by Multiples of Ten
notes: Decompose multiples of ten into tens and ones, then apply distributive reasoning to multiply quickly.

name: Skip Counting for Multiplication Facts
notes: Use bead-linked number lines and tables to extend skip-counting patterns, fill missing multiples, and solve multiplication stories.
